commit.message:
Use functools.wraps() in decorator functions

I just realized that the Spinner.__init__() documentation had gone
missing due to my omission to copy __doc__ and decided that now was
a good time to consistently adopt the proper solution!

commit.message:
Stop hiding text cursor when spinner is shown

While the code to hide the text cursor when a spinner is shown seems
simple enough, I've had it happen to me on numerous occasions that the
text cursor is successfully hidden but visibility is never restored!

I've now decided that I don't care to investigate what's going on here,
instead I will simply remove the feature, given that it's such a small
detail in the grand scheme of things (certainly not worth the bug).

verification.payload:
tree ce639c2e1c15f0f2b0eae3000367520fd2a0f18a
parent 1b79aedef69b9034c7fc7a0b8e1d8b9dbf4036d7
author Peter Odding <peter@peterodding.com> 1583093864 +0100
committer Peter Odding <peter@peterodding.com> 1583105071 +0100

Stop hiding text cursor when spinner is shown

While the code to hide the text cursor when a spinner is shown seems
simple enough, I've had it happen to me on numerous occasions that the
text cursor is successfully hidden but visibility is never restored!

I've now decided that I don't care to investigate what's going on here,
instead I will simply remove the feature, given that it's such a small
detail in the grand scheme of things (certainly not worth the bug).

commit.message:
Improve test skipping based on exception types

The humanfriendly.testing.TestCase class was originally created to
enable skipping of tests that raise specific exception types on Python
2.6. This involved patching test methods, which has the unfortunate
side effect of generating confusing pytest output on test failures.

Since then unittest2 was integrated which provided real skipping
of tests however removing the old test skipping support from the
humanfriendly.testing module would have resulted in a backwards
incompatible change, so I never bothered.

I've now decided to bite the bullet and get this over with:

1. Implement an alternative (finer grained) strategy based on a
   decorator function that applies to individual test methods.

2. Remove test method wrapping from humanfriendly.testing.TestCase.

This affects the executor and vcs-repo-mgr test suites because
they depend on the old test method wrapping approach. Both test
suites will need to be migrated to the skip_on_raise decorator.

verification.payload:
tree 1300ca4d9ea68a293876a9d2463bfe019c510814
parent e0d037dbe706e89d2e6c3067f9923b33069dd62b
author Peter Odding <peter@peterodding.com> 1583091656 +0100
committer Peter Odding <peter@peterodding.com> 1583105066 +0100

Improve test skipping based on exception types

The humanfriendly.testing.TestCase class was originally created to
enable skipping of tests that raise specific exception types on Python
2.6. This involved patching test methods, which has the unfortunate
side effect of generating confusing pytest output on test failures.

Since then unittest2 was integrated which provided real skipping
of tests however removing the old test skipping support from the
humanfriendly.testing module would have resulted in a backwards
incompatible change, so I never bothered.

I've now decided to bite the bullet and get this over with:

1. Implement an alternative (finer grained) strategy based on a
   decorator function that applies to individual test methods.

2. Remove test method wrapping from humanfriendly.testing.TestCase.

This affects the executor and vcs-repo-mgr test suites because
they depend on the old test method wrapping approach. Both test
suites will need to be migrated to the skip_on_raise decorator.

commit.message:
Start cleaning up support for spinners (extract to separate module)

The original Spinner code was written in 2013 and back then my Python
coding style was very different - I've since gained seven years of
experience (and have a much more pronounced style now). This is the
first of several cleanups intended to improve the Spinner class.

commit.message:
Get rid of broken references and noise in docs

Sphinx was emitting a screen full of warnings about unknown references.
These were bothering me because I've been working on a new Sphinx
integration and debugging that involved lots of broken references as
well 😇 so it was hard to distinguish "the forest from the trees".

Additionally the humanfriendly.compat module introduced a lot of noise
into the generated documentation because imported classes and their
members were being included in the documentation, now also fixed.

Finally I decided to start using 'sphinx-build -nW' to complain loudly
when even just one broken reference is found. This should encourage the
discipline to never introduce broken references again!

verification.payload:
tree 1b5355beac81231e67f16d6f573ad746fc782933
parent ad538da652e0bb6bf775ec491542ec245bb9aff9
author Peter Odding <peter@peterodding.com> 1583037202 +0100
committer Peter Odding <peter@peterodding.com> 1583080367 +0100

Get rid of broken references and noise in docs

Sphinx was emitting a screen full of warnings about unknown references.
These were bothering me because I've been working on a new Sphinx
integration and debugging that involved lots of broken references as
well 😇 so it was hard to distinguish "the forest from the trees".

Additionally the humanfriendly.compat module introduced a lot of noise
into the generated documentation because imported classes and their
members were being included in the documentation, now also fixed.

Finally I decided to start using 'sphinx-build -nW' to complain loudly
when even just one broken reference is found. This should encourage the
discipline to never introduce broken references again!

commit.message: Release 7.1.1: Restore Debian/Ubuntu Python 3 compatibility (distutils.spawn)

verification.payload:
tree 7b04e9a2e79967486648ba8a99f76994d170401a
parent 3545a6658cdc73d48d79a4fd7ca4ef4d525c6247
author Peter Odding <peter@peterodding.com> 1582031527 +0100
committer Peter Odding <peter@peterodding.com> 1582031527 +0100

Release 7.1.1: Restore Debian/Ubuntu Python 3 compatibility (distutils.spawn)

commit.message:
Fix Python 3 incompatibility (distutils.spawn)

Much to my dismay this morning I ran into the following breakage on a
Python 3.6 installation based on native Debian /  Ubuntu packages:

  Traceback (most recent call last):
    File "...", line 1, in <module>
      from coloredlogs.syslog import enable_system_logging
    File ".../coloredlogs/__init__.py", line 138, in <module>
      from humanfriendly import coerce_boolean
    File ".../humanfriendly/__init__.py", line 25, in <module>
      from humanfriendly.tables import format_pretty_table as format_table
    File ".../humanfriendly/tables.py", line 32, in <module>
      from humanfriendly.terminal import (
    File ".../humanfriendly/terminal.py", line 26, in <module>
      import distutils.spawn
  ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'distutils.spawn'

To enable local development and testing against lots of Python releases
I use the "deadsnakes" package repository to install 2.7, 3.4, 3.5, 3.6,
3.7 and 3.8 at the same time. Before committing 335a69bae5 I did check
the availability of the distutils.spawn module:

peter@peter-mbp> ls -l /usr/lib/python*/distutils/spawn.py
-rw-r--r-- 1 root root 8,5K nov  7 11:07 /usr/lib/python2.7/distutils/spawn.py
-rw-r--r-- 1 root root 7,4K mrt 29  2019 /usr/lib/python3.4/distutils/spawn.py
-rw-r--r-- 1 root root 7,3K nov 24 02:35 /usr/lib/python3.5/distutils/spawn.py
-rw-r--r-- 1 root root 7,3K okt 28 17:30 /usr/lib/python3.6/distutils/spawn.py
-rw-r--r-- 1 root root 7,7K okt 28 17:30 /usr/lib/python3.7/distutils/spawn.py
-rw-r--r-- 1 root root 7,7K okt 28 17:30 /usr/lib/python3.8/distutils/spawn.py

I took this to mean it would be available on all these versions. Clearly
I was wrong and this broke Python 3 compatibility. This new commit
should fix the issue by using shutil.which() on Python 3 instead.

verification.payload:
tree 20cda82ed22df88399388314b295664b0f8eb841
parent 917fa6f091e8a220e3cbbc822beacd468ce958b2
author Peter Odding <peter@peterodding.com> 1582030246 +0100
committer Peter Odding <peter@peterodding.com> 1582030246 +0100

Fix Python 3 incompatibility (distutils.spawn)

Much to my dismay this morning I ran into the following breakage on a
Python 3.6 installation based on native Debian /  Ubuntu packages:

  Traceback (most recent call last):
    File "...", line 1, in <module>
      from coloredlogs.syslog import enable_system_logging
    File ".../coloredlogs/__init__.py", line 138, in <module>
      from humanfriendly import coerce_boolean
    File ".../humanfriendly/__init__.py", line 25, in <module>
      from humanfriendly.tables import format_pretty_table as format_table
    File ".../humanfriendly/tables.py", line 32, in <module>
      from humanfriendly.terminal import (
    File ".../humanfriendly/terminal.py", line 26, in <module>
      import distutils.spawn
  ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'distutils.spawn'

To enable local development and testing against lots of Python releases
I use the "deadsnakes" package repository to install 2.7, 3.4, 3.5, 3.6,
3.7 and 3.8 at the same time. Before committing 335a69bae5 I did check
the availability of the distutils.spawn module:

peter@peter-mbp> ls -l /usr/lib/python*/distutils/spawn.py
-rw-r--r-- 1 root root 8,5K nov  7 11:07 /usr/lib/python2.7/distutils/spawn.py
-rw-r--r-- 1 root root 7,4K mrt 29  2019 /usr/lib/python3.4/distutils/spawn.py
-rw-r--r-- 1 root root 7,3K nov 24 02:35 /usr/lib/python3.5/distutils/spawn.py
-rw-r--r-- 1 root root 7,3K okt 28 17:30 /usr/lib/python3.6/distutils/spawn.py
-rw-r--r-- 1 root root 7,7K okt 28 17:30 /usr/lib/python3.7/distutils/spawn.py
-rw-r--r-- 1 root root 7,7K okt 28 17:30 /usr/lib/python3.8/distutils/spawn.py

I took this to mean it would be available on all these versions. Clearly
I was wrong and this broke Python 3 compatibility. This new commit
should fix the issue by using shutil.which() on Python 3 instead.
